editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: As it hath been acted with good applause at the private house in Drury lane, her majesty's servants.
London. Printed by T. C. for William Cooke, and are to be sold at his shop at furnivalls inn gate in Holborn. 1639.

list.head: The actors names.
list.item: Gasper de Vilarezo, an old count, father to Sebastiano, Catalina and Berinthia Sebastiano, son to Vilarezo.
Antonio a lover of Berinthia, and friend to Sebastiano.
Count de monte Nigro, a braggart .
Ansilva, a waiting gentle woman to the two sister.

div.head: To the worthily honoured, Henry Osborne esquire.
div.p: Till i be able to give you a better proof of my service, let not this oblation be despised. It is a tragedy which received encouragement and grace on the English stage; and though it come late to the impression, it was the second birth in this kind, which I dedicated to the scene, as you have art to distinguish; you have mercy and a smile, if you find a poem infirm through want of age, and experience the mother of strength. It is many years since I see these papers, which make haste to kiss your hand; if you do not accuse the boldness and pride of them; I will own the child, and believe tradition so far, that you will receive no dishonour by the acceptance; I never affected the ways of flattery: some say I have lost my preferment, by not practising that court sin; but if you dare believe, I much honour you, nor is it upon guess, but the taste and knowledge of your ability and merit; and while the court wherein you live, is fruitful with testimonies of your mind, my character is sealed up, when I have said that your virtue hath taken up a fair lodging. Read when you have leisure, and let the author be fortunate to be known

div.head: A catalogue of such things as hath been published by James Shirley gent.

list.item: Changes, or love in a maze.

div.head: Actus. 1. Scaena 1.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The noble courtesies I have received
At Lisbon worthy friend, so much engage 〈◊〉
That I must die indebted to your worth,
Unless you mean to accept what I've studied.
Although but partly to discharge the sum ▪.
Due to your honoured love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How now Sebastiano will you forfeit
The name of friend than I did hope our love
Had outgrown compliment.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I speak my thoughts,
My tongue and heart are relatives, I think
I have deserved no base opinion from you;
I wish not only to perpetuate
Our friendship, but to exchange that common name
Of friend, for

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What? take heed, do not profane;
Wouldst thou be more than friend? It is a name,
Virtue can only answer to, couldst thou
Unite into one, all goodness whatsoever
mortality can boast of, thou shalt find,.
The circle narrow bounded to contain
This swelling treasure; every good admits
Degrees, but this being so good it cannot:
For he's no friend is not superlative,
Indulgent parents, brethren , kindred, tied
By the natural flow of blood; alliances,
And what you can imagine, is to light,
To weigh with name of friend: they execute
At best, but what a nature pron ●●●e'm to,
Are often less than friends, when they remain
Our kinsmen still, but friend is never lost.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nay then Antonio you mistake, I mean not
To leave of friend, which with another title
Would not be lost, come them I'll tell you sir,
I would be friend and brother, thus our friendship
Shall like a diamond set in gold not lose
His sparkling, but show fairer; I have a pair
Of sisters, which I would commend, but that
I might seem partial their birth and fortunes
Deserving noble love; if thou beest free
From other fair engagement, I would be proud
To speak them worthy, come shalt go and see them ▪
I would not beg them suitors, fame hath spread
Through Portugal their persons, and drawn to Avero .
Many affectionate gallants.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Catalina and Berinthia

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Report speaks loud their beauties, and no less
Virtue in either well, I see you strive
To leave no 〈◊〉 where you mean to honour,
I 〈◊〉 otherwise escape the censure
Of one ingrateful, but by waiting on you
Home to Avero

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You shall honour me,
And glad my noble father, to whom you are
No stranger, your own worth before, hath been
sufficient preparation.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha?
I have not so much choice Sebastian,
But if one sister of Antonio's,
May have a commendation to your thoughts,
I will not spend much art in praising her,
Her virtue speak itself, I shall be happy,
And be confirmed you brother, though I miss
Acceptance at Avero.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Still you out do me, I could never wish
My service better placed, at opportunity
I'll visit you at Eluas, i'th mean time
Let's haste to Avero, where with you I'll bring
My double welcome, and not fail to second
Any design.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You shall teach me a lesson
Against we meet at Eluas castle sit.

div.stage: Enter Gaspar de Vilarezo, and a servant.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What gallants sirrah are they newly entered?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Count de monte Nigro my lord, and don Valasco,

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Give your observance then, I know their business;
Catalina and Berinthia are the stars
Direct them hither, Gaspar's house shall give
Respect to all, but they are two such jewels,
I must dispose maturely, I should else
Return ingratitude upon the heavens
For leaving me such pledges, not am I,
Like other fathers carried with the stream
Of love tooth youngest, as they were in birth
They had my tenderness, Catalina then
Is eldest in my care, Berinthia
Her child's part too, both fair and virtuous;
But daughters are held losses to a family,
Sons only to maintain honour and stem
Alive in their posterity, and I now think on't,
My son Sebastiano hath been slow
In his return from Lisbon, o that boy
Renews my age with hope, and hath returned
my care in education , weight for weight
With noble quality ●ty, will beloved ●●th best
Oh th' dons in Spain and Portugal, whose loves
Do often threaten his absence to such length
As 〈◊〉 hath been.
〈◊〉 here's my eldest daughter
With her amorous count, I'll not be seen,

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: You have been absent long my noble count,
Beshrew me but I dreamt on you last night.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ha ha, did you so, I tickle her in her sleep I perceive;
Sweet lady I did but like the valiant beast,
Give a little ground, to return with a greater
〈…〉, now by my father's sword
And gauntlet thou'rt a precious piece of virtue,
But prithee what didst dream of me last night?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Nay 'twas an idle dream, not worth the repartition,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Thou dreamest I warrant thee, that I was fighting
For thee up to the knee ● in blood, why I dare do't,
Such dreams are common with count de monte
Nigro, my sleeps are nothing else but rehearsals of
Battles and wounds and ambuscadoes, Donzell Delphebo
Was a mountebank of valour, Rosiclere a puff ;
My dreams deserve to be ith' chronicles,

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Why, now my dream is out,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: I dreamt that you were fighting.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: And that in single combat, for my sake
You slew a giant, and you no sooner had
Rescued my honour, but there crept a pigmy
Out of the earth, and killed you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Very likely, the valliantst man must die,

sp.speaker: Cata,
sp.l: What by a pigmy?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ay, that's another giant, I remember Hercules
Had a conflict with 'em, o my donna
Catalina I well would I were so happy once to
Maintain some honourable duel for thy sake, I shall
Ne'er be well, till I have killed somebody ; fight, 'tis true
I have never yet fleshed myself in blood ▪ nobody
Would quarrel with me, but I find my spirit prompt
If occasion would but wink at me, why not 〈◊〉 has
Nature given me these brawny arms, this manly bulk,
And these Collossian supporters nothing but to ●ling
The sledge, or pitch the bare, and play with
Axletrees ; if thou lovest me, do but command me
Some worthy service; pox a dangers I weigh 'em 〈◊〉
More than flea-bitings, would somebody did hate that
Face, now I wish it with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Would you have anybody hate me?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Yes, I'd hate 'em, I'd but thrust my hand into their
Mouth down to the bottom of their bellies, pluck
Out their lungs and shake their insides outward.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Noble sir, you need not heap more protestations,
I do believe you love me,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do you believe I love, and not accept it?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes I accept it too, but apprehend me
As men do gifts, whose acceptation does not
Bind to perform what every giver craves;
Without a stain to virgin modesty
I can accept your love, but pardon me,
It is beyond my power to grant your suit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O you too much subject a natural gift,
And make yourself beholding for your own:
The sun hath not more right to his own beams,
With which he gilds the day, nor the sea lord
Of his own waves .

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Alas, what is't to own a passion
Without power to direct it, for I move,
Not by a motion I can call my own,
But by a higher rapture , in obedience
To a father, and I have yet no freedom
To place affection, so you but endear me
Without a merit.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Here my sister.

sp.speaker: C 〈…〉
sp.l: And don Valasco, how now, are thy arrows feathered?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well enough for roving.

sp.speaker: C 〈…〉
sp.l: Roving I thought to.
〈…〉 hope fair.
〈…〉 home then, Valasco I have
〈…〉 my miseris with a paper of verses, see she
〈…〉 make 'em thyself
〈…〉 money did, what an idle question is that? as though we
That are great men, are not furnished with stipendiary
〈◊〉 am sure for my own part I can buy 'em
Cheap 〈◊〉 can make 'em a great deal, would
You have learning have no reward, she laughs
〈…〉 am glad of that.
They 〈…〉 our oh ● a true poetic fury.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Do you smell nothing, something hath some savour.
But this li ●● my think hath more more feet than the rest.
〈◊〉 run the better for that lady, I did it a purpose.

sp.speaker: Ca 〈…〉
sp.l: But here's another lame.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: That was my conceit, my own invention, lame
Halting ●●●ses, there's the greatest art, besides I
T 〈…〉 high give you to understand, that I am valiant,
〈…〉 legs and arms at all times and make 'em
Go halting home that are my enemies, I am
An ●ambographier now it i ● out.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: For honour's sake what's that?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: One of the sourest versifiers that ever crept out of
〈◊〉 when I set on't. I ●●n make anybody hang himself
With 〈◊〉 iambic ●, I can fetch blood with asclepiads
〈…〉 st ●●ad ● with hexameter and pentameter, and
Yet I have a trimeter 〈◊〉 for thee my donna Catalina
Conclude a peace sir with your passion.
I am sorry love hath been unkind to you.
To p 〈…〉 at me, who, till the first have knit
The sacred knot of marriage am forbid
To think of love.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But I cannot desist,
I am in love with every thing you say,
This your denial as it comes from you
Bids me still love you, pardon fair Berinthia,
Valasco hath not power to rule himself;
Be you less fair, or virtuous, perhaps
I may abate my service.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: Old Gaspar's house is honoured by such guests,
Now by the tomb of my progenitors,
I envied, that your fame should visit me
So oft without your person, Sebestiano
Hath been long happy in your noble friendship,
And cannot but improve himself in virtues,
That lives so near your love.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Don Antonio de Riviero.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: With whose noble worth
You oft have filled discourse, thought yourself happy
In his choice friendship; if his body carry
So many graces, it is heaven within,
Where his soul is.

sp.speaker: Vila,
sp.l: Sebastiano, thou hast largely recompensed
Thy tedious absence, you shall dishonour me,
Unless you think yourself as welcome here,
As at your Eluas castle, Vilarezo
Was once as you are sprightly, and though I say it
Maintained my father's reputation,
And honour of our house with actions
Worthy our name and family, but now,
Time hath let fall cold snow upon my hairs,
Ploughed on my brows the furrows of his anger
Disfurnished me of active blood, and wrapped me
Half in my sere cloth, yet I have mind
That bids me honour virtue, where I see it
Bud forth and spring so hopefully,

sp.speaker: Anto,
sp.l: You speak all nobleness, and encourage me
to spend the greenness of my rising years
So to 〈◊〉, that at last I may
Be old like you.
Daughters speak his welcome, Catalina.

sp.speaker: Cata
sp.l: Sir, you are most welcome.
〈…〉 she says he is most welcome, he were
Not best love her, she never made me such a reverence
For all the kisses I have bestowed upon her since
I first opened my affection, I do not like this
Fellow, I must be fair to use doctor Sharkin's cunning,
I ● we ●e not truly noble to affront him;
My blood boils in me, it shall I cool again,
The place 〈◊〉 venerable by her presence,
And I may be deceived, Valasco then
Keep 〈◊〉 with thy fears.

sp.speaker: A ●t ●.
sp.l: How now Antonio, where hast thou lost thyself?
Struck dead with lady's eyes? I could star-gaze
For ever thus, o pardon love, 'gainst whom
I often have profaned, and mocked thy fires,
Thy flames now punish me, let me collect:
They are both excellent creatures, there is
A majesty in Catalina's eye, and every part carries ambition
Or Queen upon it, yet Berinthia's
〈…〉 something more than all this praise, though she
Command the world, this hath more power o'er me ▪
Here I have lost my freedom, not the Queen
〈…〉 could thus have wounded poor Antonio '
〈◊〉 speak to her; lady I'm an novice, 〈◊〉 in love.
It may be so.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: She jests at me, yet I should be proud to be
Your servant.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I entertain no servants that are proud.
Divine Berinthia!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: She cheques my rudeness that so openly
I seem to court her, and in presence too
〈…〉 that have engaged themselves perhaps
〈◊〉 already.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: Come let us in, my house spreads to receive you,
Which you may call your own, I'll lead the way.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Please you walk sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It will become me thus to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Does not the fool ride us both?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What fool? both, whom?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: That fool, both us, we are but horses and may
Walk one another for ought I see before the door, when he
Is alight and entered, I do not relish that same
Novice, he were not best gull me; hark you don
Valasco, what shall's do?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do, why?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: This Antonio is a suitor to one of 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I fear him not.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: I do not fear him neither, I dare fight with him, and
He were ten Antonio's, but the ladies do ●, the ladies.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Berinthia, to whom
I pay my love devotions, in my ear
Seemed not to welcome him, your lady did.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I but for all that he had most mind to your 〈◊〉,
And I do not see but if he pursue it,
There is a possibility to scale the fort, ladies'
Minds may alter, by your favour, I have less
Cause to fear o'th two; if he love not Catalina ●
My game is free, and I may have a course in
Her park the more easily.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis true, he preferred service to Berinthia,
And what is she then to resist the vows
Antonio if he love, dare heap upon her?
He's gracious with her father, and a friend
Dear as his bosom to Sebastiano,
And may be is directed by that brother
To aim at her, or if he make free choice,
Berinthia's beauty will draw up his soul.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: And yet now I think on't, he was very saucy
With my love to support her arm, which she
accepted too familiarly, and she should
But love him, it were as bad for me, for though he care
Not for her, I am sure she will never abide me after it,
By this hilts I must kill him, there's no remedy,
I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll know my destiny.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: And I my fate but here he comes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The strangest resolution of a father
I ever heard, I was covetous
To acquaint him with my wishes, prayed his leave
I might be servant to Berinthia,
But thus he briefly answered, until
His eldest daughter were disposed in marriage
His youngest must not love, and therefore wished me
Unless I could place Catalina here,
Leave off soliciting, yet I was welcome,
You fed on nothing but Berinthia,
From whose fair eyes love threw a thousand flames
Into Antonio's heart, her cheeks bewraying
As many amorous blushings, which broke out
Like a forced lightning from a troubled cloud,
Discovering a restraint, as if within
She were at conflict, which her colour only
Took liberty to speak, but soon fell back,
And as it were checked by silence.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: I'll stay no longer, sir a word with you, are you desperate?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Desperate, why sit?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I ask and you be desperate, are you weary of your
Life, and you be, say but the word; somebody can tell
How to dispatch you without a physician, at a minute's warning.

sp.speaker: Ant ●.
sp.l: You are the noble count de monte Nigro.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I care not a Spanish fig what you count me, I must
Call you to account sir; in brief the lady
Donna Catalina is my mistress, I do not mean to be baffled
While this tool has any steel in't, and I have some
Mettle in myself too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The donna Catalina? do you love her?
She is a lady in whom only lives
Natures and art's perfection, born to shame
All former beauties, and to be the wonder
Of all succeeding, which shall fade and wither
When she is but remembered.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I can endure no more, diablo, he is mortally in love
With Catalina.

sp.speaker: Vala.
sp.l: 'Tis so, he's ta'en with Catalina's beauty.

sp.speaker: Count ▪
sp.l: Sir I am a servant of that lady, therefore eat up
Your words, or you shall be sensible that I am count
De monte Nigro, and she's no dish for don Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir I will do you right.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Or I will right myself.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: He did direct those praises unto me
This doth confirm it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: He cannot so soon alter,
I shall discover a passion through my eyen ▪

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Thou showest thyself a noble gentleman, the
Count is now thy friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Does it become me sir, to prosecute
Where such a noble count is interested,
Upon my soul I wish the lady yours,
Here my suit falls, with tender of my service;
Would you were married, nay in bed together
My honourable count.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Your face is cloudy sir, as you suspected
Your presence were not welcome; had you naught
But title of a brother's friendship, it were
Enough to oblige us to you, but your worth
In Catalina's eyes, bids me proclaim you
A double acceptation.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O you are bounteous lady.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Sir —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do not fear me,
I am not worthy your opinion,
It shall be happiness for me to kiss
this ivory hand,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: The whilst I kiss her lip and be immortal.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Antonio my father is a rock,
In that he first resolved, and I account it part of my
Own unhappiness, I hope you hold me not suspected,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I were unworthy such a friend, his care
Becomes him nobly; has not yonder count
Some hope of Catalina.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: My father thinks that sister worthy of
More than a bare nobility.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll back to Eluas noble sir,
This entertainment is so much above
Antonio's merit, if I leave you not
I shall be out of hope to —

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: Nay then you mock me sir, you must not leave me
Without discourtesy so soon, we trifle time,
This night you are my guest, my honoured count,
My don Valasco .

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Yes my lord, we'll follow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha I am resolved, like bargemen when they row.
I'll look another way then that I go.

div.head: Actus 2. Scaena i.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Ansilva you observe with curious eye
All gentlemen that come hither, what's your opinion.
Of don Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My opinion madam, I want art.
To judge of him.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Then without art your judgement.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: He is one of the most accomplished gentlemen
Ansilva ere beheld, pardon madam.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Nay, it doth not displease, 'You're not alone,
He hath friends to second you, and who dost think
Is cause he tarries here.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Your noble father will not let him go.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: And canst thou see no higher? than thou art dull.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Madam, I guess at something more.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Love?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Of whom?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I know not that.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: How not that? Thou'dst bring thy former truth
Into suspicion, why 'tis more apparent
Than that he loves.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: If judging eyes may guide him,
I know where he should 'Choose, but I have heard
That love is blind.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Virtue would direct him madam unto you, I know not his
Obedience, I shall repent if I offend.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.p: Thou'rt honest, be yet more free, hide not a thought that may concern it.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Then madam I think he loves my lady Berinthia;
I have observed his eyes roll that way,
Even now I spied him
Close with her in the arbour, pardon me madam.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Thou'st done me faithful service, be yet more vigilant,
I know thou speakst all truth, I do suspect him,
My sister, ha? Dare she maintain contention?
Is this the duty binds her to obey
A father's precepts, 'tis dishonour to me.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Madam, here's a pretty handsome stripling new alight,
Inquires for don Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Let me see him, 'twill give me good occasion to be
My own observer;
Whom would you sir?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I am sent in quest of Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: He speaks like a knight errant, he comes in quest,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I have heard it a little virtue in some spaniels to
Quest now and then lady.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: But you are none.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: My Mr. cannot beat me from him madam, I am one of
The oldest appurtenances belonging to him, and yet I
have little moss in my chin.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: The more to come, a witty knave.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: No more wit than will keep my head warm, I beseech you amiable virgin help my master Antonio to some intelligence that a servant of his waits to speak with him from his sister madonna Castabella.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: It shall not need sir, I'll give him notice myself,
Ansilva entertain time with him.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: A promising young man.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Do you wait on this lady?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: We are both of a tribe then, though ween differ in our sex, I beseech you tax me not of immodesty, or want of breeding, that I did not salute you upon the first view of your person, this kiss be as good as press-money to bind me to your service.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: 'You're very welcome, by my virginity.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Your virginity a good word to save an oath, for all she made me a curtsy , it was not good manners to leave me so soon 'You're very welcome by my virginity; was she afraid of breaking, it may be she is cracked already, but here she is again.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: May I beg your name sir?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: No beggar sweet, would you have it at length, than
My name is signior Baltazaro Clere Mautado,
But for brevity's sake they call me Diego.

sp.speaker: Ans,
sp.l: Then signior Diego once more you are welcome .

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Bazelez manes signiora, and what my tongue is not able to express, my head shall; it seems you have lived long a virgin.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Not above seven or eight and thirty years.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: By lady a tried virgin, you have given the world
A large testimony of your virginity.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I should be thus a disobedient daughter
A father's hests are sacred.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But in love
They have no power, it is but tyranny,
plain usurpation to command the mind
Against its own election; I am yours,
Vowed yours for ever, send me not away
Shipwrecked ith' harbour, say but you can love me,
And I will wait an age, not wish to move
But by commission from you, to whom
I render the possession of myself:
Ha? we are betrayed, I must use cunning,
She lives in you, and take not in worse sense;
You are more gracious, in that you are
So like your eldest sister, in whom lives
The copy of so much perfection,
All other seem to imitate.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Does he not praise me now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But here she is,
Madam, not finding you ith' garden,
I met this lady.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: I came to tell you
A servant of yours attends with letters from
Your sister madonna Castabella.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Diego what news?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Sir, my lady remembers her love, these letters inform you the state of all things.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.p: What serious conference had you sister with that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Would you had heard them sister, they concerned your commendations.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Why should he not deliver them to myself.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It may be then
You would have thought he flattered.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: I like not this rebound,
'Tis fairest to catch at fall.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sister, I hope
You have no suspicion, I have courted
His stay or language on my life no accent
Fell from me, your own ear would not have heard
With acceptation.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: It may be so, and yet I dare acquit you,
in duty to a father, you would wish me
All due respect, I know it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Diego.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You observe the waiting creatures in the black,
Hark, you apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: With as much tenacity as a servant.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I hope sir, now we shall enjoy you longer ▪

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The gods would sooner be sick with nectar, than antoni Antonio
Grow weary of such fair society;
But I am at home expected, a poor sister,
My father's care alive, and dying was
His legacy, having outstaid my time
Is tender of my absence.

div.stage: Enter Vilarezo, Sebastiano, count, and Valasco.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: My lord Antonio means to take his leave.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: Although last night you were inclined to go,
Let us prevail this morning.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: A servant of his, he says, brought letters
To hasten departure.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: Why sirrah, will you rob us of your master.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Not guilty my lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Sir, if you'll needs go, we'll bring you on your way.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I humbly thank your honour, I'll not be so trouble some.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Would you were gone once, I do not mean to trouble myself so much I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have now a charge upon me, I hope it may
Excuse me, if I hasten my return.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: 'Tis fair, and reasonable, well sir, my son
Shall wait on you oth' way, if any occasion
Draw you to Avero, let's hope you'll see us,
You know your welcome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My lord the favours done me, would proclaim
I were too much unworthy not to visit you,
Oft as I see Avero; madam I part with some unhappiness
To lose your presence, give me leave I may
Be absent your admirer, to whose memory
I write myself a servant,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Pox on your compliment, you were not best write
in her table-books.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: You do not know
What power you have o'er me, that but to please you
Can frame myself to take a leave so soon.

sp.speaker: Vala.
sp.l: What think you of that my lord?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Why, she says she has power to take her leave
So soon , no hurt ath' world in't, I hope she is an
Innocent lady.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The shallow rivers glide away with noise,
The deep are silent, fare you well lady.

sp.speaker: Co ●nt
sp.l: I told you he is a shallow fellow.

sp.speaker: Vala.
sp.l: I know not what to think on't Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Gentlemen happiness and success in your desires.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I'll see you a league or two.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: By any means, nay sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Diego.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: My lord I have a suit to you before I go.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: To me Diego, prithee speak it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: That while other gentlemen are happy to divide their affections among the ladies, I may have your honours leave to bear some goodwill to this virgin: Cupid hath thrown a dart at me, like a blind buzzard as he was, and there's no recovery without a cooler; if I be sent into these parts, I desire humbly I may be bolded to rub acquaintance with mistress Ansilva.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: With all my heart Diego.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Madam, I hope you will not be an enemy to a poor
Fly that is taken in the flame of the blind god.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: You shall have my consent sir.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: But what say a Ansilva, hast thou a mind to a husband?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: I fear I am too young seven years hence were time enough for me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: She's not full forty yet sir.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I honour the antiquity of her maidenhead, thou
Mistress of my heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come let's away Diego our horses —

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: We'll bring you to the game .

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Yes, we'll bring him out of doors, would we
were shut of him.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Hay ho, who would have thought I should have been in love with a stripling, have I seen so many maidenheads suffer before me, and must mine come to the block at forty years old, if this Diego have the grace to come on, I shall have no power to keep myself chaste any longer; how many maids have been overrun with this love? but here's my lady.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Sir, you love my sister.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: With an obedient heart.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Where do you think don Antonio hath made choice
To place his love?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: There where I wish it may grow older in desire,
And be crowned with fruitful happiness.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Hath your affection had no deeper root,
That 'tis rent up already, I had thought
It would have stood a winter, but i see
A summer storm hath killed it, fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How's this, a summer's storm!
Lady by the honour of your birth,
Put off these clouds, you maze me, take off
The wonder you have put upon Valasco,
And solve these riddles.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: You love Berinthia .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: With a devoted heart, else may I die
Contempt of all mankind, not my own soul
Is dearer to me.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: And yet you wish Antonio may be crowned
With happiness in his love, he loves Birinthia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Beyond expression, to see how a good nature
Free from dishonour in itself, is backward
To think another guilty, suffers itself
Be poisoned with opinion, did your eyes
Empty their beams so much in admiration
Of your Berinthia's beauty, you left none
To observe your own abuses,

sp.speaker: Vala.
sp.l: Doth not Antonio dedicate his thoughts
To your acceptance, 'tis impossible,
I heard him praise you to the heavens, above 'em;
Made himself hoarse but to repeat your virtues
As he had been in ecstasy; love Birinthia?
Hell is not blacker than his soul, if he
Love any goodness but yourself.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: That lesson he with impudence hath read
To my own ears, but shall I tell you sir?
We are both made but properties to raise
Him to his partial ends, flattery is
The stalkeing horse of policy, saw you not,
How many flames he shot into her eyes
When they were parting, for which she paid back
Her subtle tears, he wrung her by the hand,
Seemed with the greatness of his passion
To have been o'er born, o cunning treachery!
Worthy our justice, true be commended me;
But could you see the fountain that sent forth
So many cozening streams, you would say Styx
Were Christ all to it, and waste not to the count,
Whom he supposed was in pursuit of me;
Nay, whom he knew did love me, that he might
Fire him the more to consummate my marriage
That I disposed he might have of access
To his beloved Berinthia, the end
Of his desires I can confirm it, he prayed
To be so happy with my father's leave
To be her amorous servant, which he nobly
Denied, partly expressing your engagements;
If you have least suspicion of this truth:
But d'ye think she love you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I cannot challenge her, but she has let fall
Something to make me hope, how think you she's
Affected to Antonio?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: May be
Luke warm as yet, but soon as as she's caught,
Inevitably his, without prevention.
For my own part I hate him in whom lives
A will to wrong a gentleman, for he was
Acquainted with your love, 'twas my respect
To tender so your injury, I could not
Be silent in it ▪ what you mean to do
I leave to your own thoughts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O stay sweet lady, leave me not to struggle
Alone with this universal affliction;
You speak even now Berinthia would be his
Without prevention, o that antidote,
That balsam to my wound.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Alas I pity you, and the more, because
I see your troubles so amaze your judgement,
I'll tell you my opinion sir oth' sudden;
For him, he is not worth Valasco's anger;
Only thus, you shall discover to my father,
She promised you her love, be confident
To say you did exchange faith to her; this alone
May chance assure her, and if not I have't:
Steal her away, your love I see is honourable,
So much I suffer when desert is wounded,
You shall have my assistance, you apprehend me,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am devoted yours, command me ever.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Keep smooth your face, and still maintain your worship
With Berinthia, things must be managed
And struck in the maturity, noble sir; i wish
You only fortunate in Berinthia's love.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Words are too poor to thank you, I look on you
As my safe guiding star.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: But I shall prove a wandering star, I have
A course which I must finish for myself.
Glide on thou subtle mover, thou hast brought
This instrument already for thy aims,
Sister, I'll break a serpent's egg betimes,
And tear Antonio from thy very bosom,
Love is above all law of nature, blood,
Not what men call, but what that bides is good.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Be not so careful coz, your brothers well.
Be confident if he were otherwise
You should have notice, whom hath he to share
Fortunes without you? all his ills are made
Less by your bearing part, his good is doubled
By your communicating.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: By this reason
All is not well, in that my ignorance
What fate hath happened, bars me off the portion
Belongs to me sister, but my care
Is so much greater, in that Diego whom
I charged to put on wings, if all were well,
Is dull in his return.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: His master happily hath commanded him
To attend him homewards, this is recompensed
Already, look they are come;
You're welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O sister, ere you let fall words of welcome,
Let me unlade a treasure in your ear
Able to weigh down man.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What treasure brother, you amaze me,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Never was man so blessed,
As heavens had studied to enrich me here,
So am I fortunate.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You make me covetous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have a friend.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You have a thousand sir, is this your treasure?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But I have one more worth than millions,
And he doth only keep alive that name
Of friendship in his breast, pardon Villandras,
'Tis not to strain your love, whom I have tried,
My worthiest cozen.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: But where is this same friend, why came he not
To Eluas with you, sure he cannot be
Dear to you brother, to whom I am not indebted
At least for you.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I have many dear friends too, my tailor is one
To whom I am indebted

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: His commission
Stretched not so far, a father's tie was on him,
But I have his noble promise, ere't be long,
We shall enjoy him.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Brother I hope
You know how willingly I can entertain
Your bliss, and make it mine, pray speak the man
To whom we owe so much.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Twere not charity to starve you thus with shadows,
Take him and with him in thy bosom lock
The mirror of fidelity, don Sebastiano.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I oft have heard you name him full of worth,
And upon that relation have laid up,
One dear to my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But he must be dearer Castabella, hark you sister,
I have been bold upon thy virtue, to
Invite him to you, if your heart be free.
Let it be empty ever, if he do not
Fill it with noblest love, to make relation,
What zeal he gave of a worthy nature,
At our last parting (When betwixt a son,
And friend he so divided his affections
And out did both) you would admire him: were
I able I would build a temple where
We took our leave,
The ground itself was hallowed
So much with his own piety, Diego saw it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Yes sir, I saw, heard, and wondered.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come I will tell you all, to your chamber sister,
Diego ▪ our plot must on, all time is lost
Until we try the moving.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: If the plot please you sir, let me alone to play my part
I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come Castabella, ● and prepare to hear
A story not of length but worthy your ear.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You have not dealt so honourably sir,
As did become you, to proceed so far
without my knowledge, give me leave to tell you
You are not welcome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My lord I am sorry,
If I have any way transgressed, I was not
Respectless of your honour, nor my fame,
Valasco shall be unhappy, if by him
You shall derive a stain, my actions fair,
I have done nothing with Berinthia,
To merit such a language, 'twas not ripe,
For me to interrupt the father, when I knew not
What grace I hold with her.

sp.speaker: Vil,
sp.l: Hell on her grace, is this her duty? ha,
I can forget my nature if she dare
Make so soon forfeit of her piety;
O where is that same awful dread of parent,
Should live in children; 'tis her ambition
To out run her sister, but I'll curb her impudence,

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Retire yourself, this passion must have way,
This works as I would have it, fear nothing sir,
Obscure.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I'll cloister her, and starve this spirit
Makes her deceive my trust; Catalina
Upon thy duty I command thee, take
Her custody on thee, keep her from the eye
Of all that come to Averro, let her discourse
With pictures on the wall, I fear she hath
Forgotten to say her prayers, is she grown sensual?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: But my lord.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: O keep thy accents for a better cause,
She hath contemned us both, thou caused not see
What blemish she derives unto our name.
Yet these are sparks, he hath a fire within,
Will turn all into flames, where's Valasco?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Good sir, a much afflicted worthy gentleman,
At your displeasure.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Thou art too full of pity, nay thou'rt cruel
To thy own fame, he must not have access
To prosecute , it was my doting sin,
of too much confidence in Berinthia,
Gave her such liberty, on my blessing punish it,
'Twill be a virtuous act, the snow I thought
Was not more innocent, more cold, more chaste
Why my command bound her in ribs of ice,
But she's dissolved, to thee I'll leave her now,
Be the maintainer of thy father's vow,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why I am undone now,

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Nothing less, this conflict
Prepares your peace, I am her guardian,
Love smiles upon you, I am not inconstant,
Having more power to assist you, but away,
We must not be descried, expect ere long
To here what you desire.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My bliss I remember.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Berinthia, you're my prisoner, at my leisure
I'll study on your fate, I cannot be
Friend to myself, when I am kind to thee.

div.head: Actus. 3. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter Sebastiano, Berinthia, Ansilva, Diego meets them ▪

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Welcome honest Diego, your master Antonio is in health I hope.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: He commanded me, remember his service to you, I have obtained his leave for a small absence to perfect a suit I lately commenced in this court.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You follow it close methinks Berinthia, I see this cloud
Vanish already, be not dejected , soon
I'll know the depth on't ▪ should the world forsake thee,
Thou shalt not want a brother dear Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: This is my lady Berinthia, prithee let me show
Some manners, madam my master Antonio speaks his
Service to you in this paper: alas madam, I was but
Half at home, and I am returned to see if I can recover
the tother piece of myself, so, was it not a reasonable
Compliment.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Antonio, he's constant i perceive.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: So, we are alone, sweet mistress Ansilva, i am bold
To renew my suit, which lest it should either
Fall or depend too long having passed my declaration,
I shall desire to come to a judgement.
My cause craves nothing but justice,
That is, that you would be mine; and now since
You self is judge also, I beseech you be not partial
In your own cause, but give sentence for the plaintiff, and
I will discharge the fees of the court on this fashion.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Here is a haven yet to rest my soul on,
In midst of all unhappiness, which I look on,
With the same comfort a distressed sea man
Afar off, views the coast he would enjoy,
When yet the seas do toss his reeling bark,
Twixt hope and danger, thou shalt be concealed.

div.stage: She mistaking as she moved put up the letter, it falls down ▪

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Here's my lady Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: What care I for my lady Berinthia, and she thinks
Much, would she had one to stop her mouth.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: But I must observe her, upon her father's displeasure,
She is committed to my lady's custody, who hath made
Me her keeper, she must be locked up.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Ha locked up.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Madam, it is now time you would retire to your own chamber.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes, prithee do Ansilva in this gallery,
I breathe but too much air, o Diego you'll have
An answer I perceive, ere you return.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: My journey were to no purpose else madam ▪ I apprehend her . I'll wait an opportunity , alas poor lady , is my sweet heart become a jailor , there's hope of an office without money.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p:
Diego I spy my lady Catalina coming this way, pray shroud yourself behind this cloth, I would be loath she
should ice us here together, quickly, I hear her treading,

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Ansilva.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Who's with you?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Nobody madam.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Was not Diego with you, Antonio's man?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: He went from me madam half an hour ago,
To visit friends ith' city.

sp.speaker: Caf.
sp.l: He hath not seen Berinthia I hope.

sp.speaker: A ●ss
sp.l: Unless he can pierce stone walls madam, I am sure ▪

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Direct don Valasco hither by the back stairs,
I expect him.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I shall madam.

sp.speaker: Cat ▪
sp.l: Ha , what's this? A letter to Berinthia ▪ from whom
Subscribed? Antonio, what devil brought this hither?
Furies torment me not, ha, while I am Antonio ▪ expect
Not I can be other than thy servant, all my thoughts
Are made sacred with thy remembrance, whose hope
Sustains my life, o I drink poison from these fatal accents,
Be thy soul blacker than the ink that stains
The cursed paper, would each drop had fallen
From both your hearts, and every character
Been texed with blood, I would have tired mine eyes
To have read you both dead here, upon my life
Diego hath been the cunning Mercury
In this conveyance, i suspect his love
Is but a property to advance this suit.
But I will cross 'em all;
Don Valasco, you are seasonably arrived,
I have a letter for you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For me?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: It does concern you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: How do you like it sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As I should a poniard sticking here, how came
You by it?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: I found it here by accident oth' ground,
I am sure it did not grow there, I suppose
Diego, the servant of Antonio
Who colourably pretends affection
to Ansilva, brought it, he's the agent for him.
Now the design appears, day is not more conspicuous
Than this cunning.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am resolved,

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Antonio or I must change our air,
This is beyond my patience ▪ sleep in this
And never wake to honour, o my fates,
He takes the freehold of my soul away,
Berinthia, and it, are but one creature,
I have been a tame fool all this while,
Swallowed my poison in a fruitless hope,
But my revenge, as heavy as Jove's wrath,
Wrapped in a thunderbolt is falling on him,

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Now you appear all nobleness, but collect
Draw up your passions to a narrow point
Of vengeance, like a burning glass that fires
Surest ith' smallest beam, he that would kill,
Spends not his idle fury to make wounds,
Far from the heart of him he fights withal,
Look where you most can danger, let his head
Bleed out his brains, or eyes, aim at that part
Is dearest to him, this once put to hazard,
The rest will bleed to death.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Apply this madam.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: The time invites to action, I'll be brief,
Strike him through Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Mistake me not, I am her sister,
She is his heart, make her your own, you have
A double victory, thus you may kill him
With most revenge, and give your own desires,
A most confirmed possession, fighting with him,
Can be no conquest to you, if you mean
To strike him dead, pursue Berinthia,
And kill him with the wounds he made at you,
It will appear but justice, all this is
Within your fathom sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis some divinity hangs on your tongue.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: If you consent Berinthia shall not see,
more suns till you enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How dear madam.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 you shall steal her away ▪
O when '

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Provide
〈…〉 friends, but let it not be known
Upon your honour, I assist you in't.
And after 〈◊〉 when soft sleepe hath charmed
All senses 〈◊〉 the garden gate.
Which shall to open for you, to know her chamber
A candle shall direct you in the window,
〈◊〉 shall attend too, and provide
To give you entrance, thence take Berinthia,
And soon convey her to what place you think
〈◊〉 and most convenient, in small time
You may procure your own conditions ▪
But sir you must engage yourself to use her
With honourable respects, she is my sister,
Did not I think you noble, for the world
I would not run that hazard.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let heaven forsake me then, was ever mortal
So bound to woman's care, my mothers was
Half paid her at my birth, but you have made me
An everlasting debtor.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Select your friend, bethink you of a place
You may transpose her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am all wings.

sp.speaker: Cat ▪
sp.l: So, when gentle physic will not serve, we must
Apply more active, but there is
Yet a receipt behind; Valasco's shallow,
And will be planet struck, to see Berinthia
Die in his arms: 'tis so, yet he himself
Shall carry the suspicion, if art,
Or hell can furnish me with such a poison,
Sleepe thy last sister, whilst thou livest I have,
No 〈◊〉 in my , my rest thy grave.

div.stage: Diego comes from behind the hangings.

sp.l: Go thy ways, and the devil wants a breeder thou
art for him, one spirit and herself are able to furnish
Hell and it were unprovided; but I am glad I heard all
I shall love hangings the better while I live:
I perceive some good may be done behind 'em ▪
But I'll acquaint my lady Berinthia,
Here's her chamber I observed: madam, madam
Berinthia,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: 'Tis I Diego, I am Diego.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Honest Diego, what good news,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: You're undone, undone lost, undone for ever; it is time now to be serious.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Where's my master Antonio's letter.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Here, where, ha, alas, I fear I have lost it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Alas you have undone yourself, and your sister, my lady Catalina hath found it, and is mad with rage, and envy against you; I overheard your destruction, she hath showed it to don Valasce, and hath plotted that he shall steal you away this night, the doors shall be lest open the hour after twelve.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You amaze me, 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Do not cast away yourself, by incredulity, upon my life your fate is cast, nay more, worse than that.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Worse?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: You must be poisoned too, o she's a cunning devil, and she will carry it so, that Valasco shall be suspected for your death , what will you do?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am overcome with amazement?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Madam remember with what noble love my master Antonio does honour you, and now both save yourself, and make him happy, how.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am lost man.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Fear not, I will engage my life for your safety,
Seem not to have knowledge or suspicion, be careful
What you receive, lest you be poisoned, leave the
Rest to me, I have a crotchet in my pate shall spoil
Their music, and prevent all danger I warrant you,
by any means be smooth, and pleasant, the devils
A knave, your sisters a traitor, my master is your noble
Friend, I am your honest servant, and Valasco shall
Shake his ears like an animal.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It is not to be hoped for.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Then cut of my ears, slit my nose, and make a devil of me, shall I about it say, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Any thing thou art honest, heaven be near,
Still to my innocence, I am full of fear.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Spur cut and away then.

div.stage: Enter signior Sharkino in his study, furnished with glasses, viols, pictures of wax characters, wands, conjuring ●●t, powders paintings, and Scarabeo.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Scarabeo.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Is the door tongue tide, screw yourself half out a ● one of the crevices, and give me notice what patient approaches me.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: I can run through the key hole sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: This fucus bears
A lively tincture, o the check must blush
That wears it, their deceived that say
Art is the ape of nature.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Who is't?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: My ladies apron-strings, mistress Ansilva her chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Admit her.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: How now raw head and bloody bones, where's the
Doctor Sharkino? o here he is.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: How does your virtuous lady.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: In good health sir.
Where's the fucus, and the powder.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: All is prepared here.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: To see what you can do, many make legs, and you make faces sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p:
Variety of faces is now in fashion, and all little enough for some to set a good face on't, o ladies may now and then commit 〈◊〉 and have some colour for't, but these are but 〈…〉 of our art, the things we can prescribe to be taken
inwardly, are pretty curiosities, we can prolong life.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: And kill too can you not?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: O any that will go to the price.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: You have poisons I warrant you, how do they look ▪ pray let's see one.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: O natural and artificial, Nessa's blood was milk
To 'em, an extraction of toads and vipers, look
Here's a parcel of Claudius Caesar's posset,
Given him by his wife Agrippina here is some of
Hannibal's medicine he carried always in the
Pommel of his sword, for a dead lift, a very active
Poison, which passing the orifice, kindles
Straight a fire inflames the blood, and makes marrow
Fly, have you occasion to apply one.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Introth we are troubled with a rat in my lady's chamber.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: A rat, give him his bane, would you destroy a city, I have probatinus of Italian salads, and our own country figs shall do it rarely, a rat, I have scarce a poison so base, the worst is able to kill a man, I have all sorts, from a minute to seven years in operation, and leave no marks behind 'em, 'a rat's a rat.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Pray let me see a remover at twelve hours, and I would be loath to kill the poor thing presently.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Here, you may cast it away upon't, but 'tis a disparagement to the poison.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: This will content you.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Because it is for a rat you shall pay no more, my service to my lady, my poisons howsoever I give them, variety of operations are all but one. Knocks within.honest rat's bane in severall-shapes, their virtue is common, and will not be long in killing; you were best look it be a rat, Scarabeo.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Sir here's a gallant inquires for doctor Sharkino

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Usher him in, it is some don.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Is your name signior Sharkino the famous doctor .

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: They call me Sharkino.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Your gracious pardon.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: 〈…〉 monte Nigro.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Your honour's sublimity doth illustrate this habitation ▪
Is there any thing wherein Sharkino may express
〈…〉 service? if ought within the circumference
Of a medicinal or mathematical science,
May have acceptance with your celsitude ,
It shall devolve itself.

sp.p: Devolve itself, that word is not in my table book; what are all these trinkets?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Take 〈◊〉 I beseech your honour , they are dangerous, this is the Devil's 〈◊〉,

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: A pox o'th' devil, what have I do with him,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: It is a dreadful circle of conjuration, fortified
With sacred characters against the power
Of infernal spirits, within whose round I can tread
Safely , when hell burns round about me.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Not unlikely.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Will you see the devil sir?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Ha, the devil? not at this time, I am in some haste,
Any thing but the devil I durst fight with all, hark
You doctor, letting these things pass, hearing
Of your skill, I am come in my own person , for
A fragment of your art, hark you, have you any
〈◊〉 to procure love sir?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: All the degrees of it this is ordinary.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Nay I would not have it too strong, the lady I intend it for, is pretty well taken already, an easing working thing does it.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Here's a powder whose ingrediences were fetched
From Arabia the happy, a sublimation of the phoenix
Ashes, when she last burned herself, it bears the
Colour of cinnamon, two or three souples put into
A cup of wine, fetches up her heart 〈◊〉 can scarce
Keep it in, for running out of her mouth to you
My noble lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: That, let me have that, doctor I know 'tis dear,
Will that gold buy it?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Your honour is bountiful, there needs no circumstance, minister it by whom you please, your intention binds it to operation.

sp.speaker: Co ●t
sp.l: So, so Catalina, I will put your morning's draught
In my pocket —Knock at the door
Doctor, I would not be seen.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Please you my lord obscure yourself behind these hangings then, till they be gone, I'll dispatch 'em the sooner; or if your honour think fit, 'tis but clouding your person with a simple cloak of mine, and you may at pleasure pass without discovery, my anatomy shall wait on you.
Prithee come back yet.
O by any means go laynes.
Dost thou think it possible that any man can tell where thy things are, but he that stole 'em, he's but a juggling imposter, a my conscience, come back again.

Nay now we are at furthest, be not ruled by him, I know he is a cunning man, he told me my fortune once when I was to go a journey by water, that if I scaped drowning, I should do well enough, and I have lived ever since.
Well I will try, I am resolved; stay, here he is Pedro, you are acquainted with him, break the ice, he is alone.

Bless you Mr. doctor; sir presuming on your art, here is a fellow of mine, indeed the butler, for want of a better; has lost a dozen of diaper spoons, and half a dozen of silver napkins yesterday, they were seen by all three of us in the morning between six and seven set up, and what spirit of the buttery hath stolen 'em before eight, is invisible to our understanding.
He hath delivered you the case right: I beseech you sir do what you can for a servant, that is like to be in a lamentable case else, here's a gratuity.
Now we shall see what the devil can do, heigh, here's one of his spirits I think.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p:
Between 7 and 8. the hour; the 1 luna, the 2 Saturn,
the 3 Jupiter, the 4 Mars, the 5 sol, the 6 Venus , the 7 Mercury, ha then it was stolen, Mercury is a thief, your goods are stolen.

sp.l: Was Mercury the thief, pray where dwells he?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Mercury is above the moon man.
Alas sir 'tis a great way thither.
Did not I tell you you would be gulled.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Well you're a servant, I'll do something for you; what will you say, if I show you the man that stole your spoons and napkins presently, will that satisfy you.

sp.l: I'll desire no more, o good Mr. doctor.
If he does that, I'll believe he has cunning.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Go to, hears a glass.
Lo you there now.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Stand your backs North, and stir not till I bid you;
What see you there?
Here's nothing.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Look again, and mark, stand yet more North.
Now I see somebody. 1 and I.

div.stage: The count comes from behind the hangings and muff in a cloak steals of the stage.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Mark this fellow muffled in the cloak, he hath stolen your spoons and napkins, does he not skulk.
'Foote 'tis strange, he looks like a thief, this doctor I see is cunning.

sp.l: O rogue how shall's come by him, o for an officer,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Yet stir not,
O he's gone, where is he?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Be not too rash, my art tells me there is danger in't, you must be blindfold all, if you observe me not, all is to no purpose, you must not see till you be forth a doors, shut your eyes, and lead one another, when you are abroad open them and you shall see again.

sp.l: The thief?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: The same, then use your pleasures, so, be sure you see not, conduct them Scarabeo.

div.stage: Enter a maid with an Urinal.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
O Mr. doctor I have got this opportunity to come
to you, but I cannot stay, here's my water, pray sweet Mr. doctor, tell me, I am in great fear that I have lost —

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My maidenhead sir, you can tell by my water.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Dost not thou know?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O I do some what doubt myself, for this morning when I rose, I found a pair of breeches on my bed, and I have had a great suspicion ever since, it is an evil sign they say, and one does not know what may be in those breeches sometimes; sweets Mr. doctor, am I a maid still or no, I would be sorry to lose my maiden head ere I were aware, I fear I shall never be honest after it.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Let me see Urina meretrix; the colour is a strumpet, but the contents deceive not, your maiden head is gone.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And is there no hope to find it again?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: You are not everybody , by my art, as in other things that have been stolen, he that hath stolen your maiden head shall bring it again.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Thank you sweet Mr. doctor, I am in your debt for this good news; o sweet news sweet Mr. doctor.

div.stage: Enter count beating before him the three serving-men, they run in.

sp.l: Cry your honour mercy, good my lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Out you slaves, o my toes.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What ails your lordship?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Doctor, I am out of breath, where be these worms crept, I was never so abused since I was swaddled: hark you; those 3. Rogues that were here even now, began to lay hold of me, and told me I must give them their spoons and napkins; they made a thief of me, but I think I have made their flesh jelly with kicks and bastinadoes; o I have no mercy when I set on't, I have made 'em all poor Johns, impudent varlets; talk to me of spoons and napkins.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Alas one of them was mad, and brought to me to cure him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Nay they were all mad, but I think I have madded 'em; I fear i have kicked two or three out of their lives; alas
poor wretches I am sorry for it now, but I have such an humour of beating and kicking when my foots in once: hark you doctor, is it not within the compass of your physic to take down a man's courage a thought lower; the truth is, I am apt of myself to quarrel upon the least affront ith' world, I cannot be kept in, chains will not hold me: tother day for a less matter than this, I kicked half a dozen of high Germans, from one end of the street to the other, for but offering to shrink between me and wall; not a day goes o'er my head but I hurt somebody mortally; pox a these rogues, I am sorry at my heart I have hurt 'em so, but I can not forbear.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How? I can scarce forbear striking you now, for saying it is strange; you would not think it: o the wounds i have given for a very look; well hark you, if it be not too late, I would be taken down, but I fear 'tis impossible, and then every one goes in danger of his life by me.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Take down your spirit, look you, d'ye see this inch and a half, how tall a man do you think he was? He was twelve cubits high, and three yards' compass at the waste when I took him in hand first, I'll draw him through a ring ere I have done with him: I keep him now to break my poisons, to eat spiders and toads, which is the only dish his heart wishes for; a capon destroys him, and the very sight of beef or mutton makes him sick; look, you shall see him eat his supper, come on your ways, what say you to this spider? look how he leaps.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: O dainty.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Here, saw you that? how many legs now for the haunch of a toad.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: Twenty, and thank you sir, o sweet toad, o admirable toad.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: This is very strange, I ne'er saw the like, I never knew spiders and toads were such good meats before; will he not burst now?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p:
It shall ne'er swell him, by tomorrow he shall be an
inch abated, and I can with another experiment plump him and heighten him at my pleasure; I'll warrant I'll take you down my lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay but d'ye here, do I look like a spider-catcher, or toad-eater.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Far be it from Shirkino, I have gentle pellets for your lordship, shall melt in your mouth, 'And take of your valour insensibly; lozenges that shall comfort your stomach, and but at a week restrain your fury two or three thoughts; does your honour think I would forget myself, I show you by this rat what I can do by art: your lordship shall have an easy composition, no hurt ith' world in't; here take but half a dozen of these going to bed, ere morning; it shall work gently, and in the virtue appear every day afterwards.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But if I find myself breaking out into fury, I may take 'em often; here's for your pellets of lozenges, what rare physic is this? I'll put it in practise presently, farewell doctor.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Happiness wait on your egregious lordship, my physic shall make your body soluble, but for working on your spirit, believe it when you find it; with any lies we must set forth siour'mples and compositions to utter them: so this is a good day's work; lean chaps lay up, and because you have performed handsomely, there is some silver for you, lay up my properties: 'tis night already, thus we knaves will thrive, when honest plainness know not how to live.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Art sure she has ta'en it?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: As sure as I am alive? she never eat with
Such an appetite, for I found none left, I would
Be loath to have it so sure in my belly, it will work
Rarely twelve hours hence.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Thus we work sure then, time runs upon
Th' appointed hour, Valasco should rid me of all my
fears at once, upon thy life be careful to direct
Him at his first approach, I am sick till she
Be delivered; be secret as the night, I'll to my
Chamber, be very careful.

div.stage: Enter Antonio, Villandras, Diego, vizarded and armed .

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Art sure thou hast the time right.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Doubt not, yonder's her chamber, the light speaks it; softly.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Who's there? Vallasco?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: That way, make no noise, things are prepared, softly
So, so, this is good I hope and weight too, my lady
Berinthia will be sure enough anon, I shall ne'er
Get more higher, I had much ado to persuade her
To the spice, but I swore it was a cordial my lady
Used herself, and poor fool she has swallowed it
Sure.

div.stage: Enter Ant, with Berinthia, villain, Diego.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam fear not I am your friend.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Stop her mouth, away.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: So, so, they are gone, alas poor Valasco I pity thee,
But we creatures of politic ladies must hold the
Same bias with our mistresses, and 'tis some policy
To make them respect us the better, for fear our
Teeth be not strong enough to keep in our tongues:
Now must I study out some tale by morning to salute
My old lord withal.

div.stage: Enter V Valasco , a friend or two armed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ansilva?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Somebody calls me, who is it?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is I Valasco

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: What comes he back for? I hope the poison does
Not work already, where have you disposed her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Disposed whom?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My lady Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let me alone to dispose her, prithee where's the light?
Show us the way.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: What way?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The way to her chamber? come, I know what
you are sick of, here each minute is an age till
I possess Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: This is pretty, I hope my lady is well.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My lady Berinthia sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do you mock me?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I mock you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I shall grow angry, lead me to
Berinthia's chamber, or —

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Why sir, were not you here even now, and hurried
Her away, I have your gold well fare all good tokens;
I have performed my duty already sir, and you had my
Lady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am abused you are a cunning devil, I hear and had
Berinthia, tell me, or with this pistol, I will soon
Reward thy treachery, where Berinthia?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O I beseech you do not fright me so, if you were
Not here even now, here was another that called
Himself Valasco, to whom I gave access, and
He has carried her away.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Am I awake? or do I dream this horror:
Where am I? who does know me, are you friends
Of don Valasco?
Do you doubt us sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I doubt myself, who am I
Our noble friend Valasco,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis so, I am Valasco, all the furies
Circle me round, o teach me to be mad,
I am abused, infufferably tormented,
My very soul is whipped, it had been safer
For Catalina to have played with serpents.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Thou talkest of wonders, where is Valasco?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: He was here even now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who named Valasco?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: 'Twas I, Catalina, here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Could you pick none out of the stock of man
To mock but me, so basely?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Valasco be yourself, resume your virtue.
My thoughts are clear from your abuse, it is
No time to vent our passions, fruitless rages,
Some hath abused us both, but a revenge
As swift as lightning shall pursue their flight:
O I could fear my brains, as you respect
Your honour's safety, or Berinthia's love;
Haste to your lodging, which being near our house,
You shall be sent for; seem to be raised up,
Let us alone to make a noise at home,
Fearful as thunder; try the event, this cannot
Do any hurt, you Ansilva shall
With clamours wake the household cunningly,
While I prepare myself.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will suspend awhile.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Help, help, thieves, villains, murder my lady:
Help o my lord, my lady, murder thieves help.

div.stage: Enter Sebastiano in his first with a taper.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What fearful cry is this, where are you?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Here o I am almost killed.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ansilva where art hurt?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: All over sir, my lady Berinthia is carried away
By ruffians, that broke into her chamber, alas
Sees gone.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Whether? which way?
My sister Berinthia is violently ta'en out of her
Chamber, and here's Ansilva hurt, see look about,
Berinthia sister.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: How Berin. gone ? call up the servants,
Ansilva, how wast?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Alas madam, I have not my senses about me, I am so
Frighted, vizards, and swords, and pistols, but my
Lady Berinthia was quickly seized upon, she's gone.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What villains durst attempt it?
sp.stage: Enter count monte de Nigro with a torch.
sp.l: I fear Valasco guilty of this rape.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Run one to his lodging presently, it will appear
I know he loved her, o my lord, my sister Berinthia's lost,

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: How? foot my physic begins to work, I'll come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Where's Diego? he is missing, run one to his chamber, here's Valasco.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It is apparent sir, Valasco's noble.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Berinthia's stolen away.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Her chamber broken ope , and she ta'en thence this night.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Confusion stay the thief.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: So, so, as you were saying, Berinthia was stolened ● weigh by somebody , and —

sp.speaker: I. servant
sp.l: Diego is not in his chamber.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Didst break ope the door?

sp.speaker: I. servant
sp.l: I did, and found all empty.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: How, Diego gone? that's strange, o it workers again, I'll come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I do suspect —
This some plot of Antonio,
Diego, a subtle villain,
Confirms himself an instrument by this absence;
What thinkest Ansilva?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Indeed I heard some of them name Antonio.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Seb.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: 'Tis true upon my soul, o false Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Unworthy gentleman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let none have the honour to revenge, but I the wronged
Valasco , let me beg it sir.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Antonio, boy up before the day,
Upon my blessing I command thee post
To Eluas castle, summon that false man
To quit his shameful action, bid him return
Thy sister back, whose honour will be lost
For ever in't, if he shall dare deny her,
Double thy father's spirit, call him to
A strict account, and with thy sword enforce him,
O I could leap out of my age methinks ,
And combat him myself : be thine the glory,
This stain will never wash off, I feel it settle
On all our blood, away, my curse pursue
This disobedience.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I had an interest in Berinthia,
Why have not I commission, I have a sword,
Thirsteth to be acquainted with his veins;
It is too mean a satisfaction
To have her rendered, on his heart I'd write
A most just vengeance.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sir she is my sister, I have a sword dares tent
A wound as far as any; spare your valour

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I have a trick to be rid of this fool, my lord
Do you accompany my brother, you
I know are valiant .

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Any whither, I'll make me ready presently .

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: My most unhappy sister.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: O I could surfeit, I am confident
Antonio hath her, 'tis revenge beyond
My expectation, to close up the eyes
Of his Berinthia, dying in his arms,
Poisoned maturely, mischief I shall prove
Thy constant friend, let weakness virtue love.

div.head: Actus 4. Scaena i.
div.stage: Enter Antonio , Berinthia, Castabella, Villandras, Sforza, Diego.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The welcomest guest that ever Eluas had
Sister, Villandras you're not sensible what treasure
You possess , I have no loves, I would not here divide.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Indeed madam, you're as welcome here, as are my mother was.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: And you are here as safe, as if you had an army for your guard.

sp.speaker: S ●or
sp.l: Safe armies, and guard; Berinthia you're a lady,
But I mean not to court you: guard ●notha, here's
A Toledo, and an old arm, tough bones and sinews,
Able to cut off as stout a head as wags upon a shoulder,
Thou'rt Antonio's guest, welcome by the old bones
Of his father, thou'st a wall of brass about thee
My young daffodil .

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Nor think my noble cousin meaneth you any dishonour here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dishonour, it is a language I never understood, yet
Throw off your fears Berinthia, you're ith' power
Of him that dares not think
The least dishonour to you.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.p: True by this buss jerkin, that hath looked ith' face of an army, and he lies like a termagant, denies it, Antonio is lord of the castle, but I'll command fire to the guns, upon ● any renegado that confronts us, set thy heart at rest my gillyflower, we are all friends I warrant thee, and he's a Turk that does not honour thee from the hair of thy head, to thy pettitoes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come be not sad.

sp.speaker: Cas ●.
sp.l: Put on fresh blood, you're not cheerful, how do you?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I know not how, nor what to answer you,
Your loves I cannot be ungrateful to,
You're my best friends I think, but yet I know not
With what consent you brought my body hither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can you be ignorant what plot was laid
To take your fair life from you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: If all be not a dream, I do remember
Your servant Diego told me wenders, and
I owe you for my preservation, but —

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.p: Shoot not at butts, Cupid's an archer, here a fair mark, a f fools bolts soon shot, my names Sforza still, my double daisy.

sp.speaker: Cast
sp.p: It is your happiness you have escaped the malice of your sister.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: And it is worth
A noble gratitude to have been quit,
By such an honourer as Antonio is
Of fair Berinthia .

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O but my father, under whose displeasure I ever sink,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are secure

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: As the poor deer that being pursued, for safety
Gets up a rock that over hangs the sea,
Where all that she can see, is her destruction,
before the waves, behind her enemies
Promise her certain ruin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Feign not yourself so hapless my Berinthia ,
Raise your dejected thoughts, be merry, come,
Think I am your Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: It is not wisdom
To let our passed fortune, trouble us,
Since were they bade the memory is sweet,
That we have passed them, look before you lady,
The future most concerneth.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You have awaked me, Antonio pardon,
Upon whose honour I dare trust myself,
I am resolved if you dare keep me here,
T'expect some happier issue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dare keep thee here? with thy consent, I dare
Deny thy father, by this sword I dare,
And all the world.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.p: Dare, what giant of valour dates hinder us, from daring to slit the weasands of them that dare say, we dare not do any thing, that is to be dared under the poles, I am old Sforza, that in my days have scoured rogues faces with hot balls, made 'em cut cross capers, and sent them away with a powder, I have a company of roaring bulls upon the walls, shall spit fire in the faces of any ragamuffin that dares say, we dare not fight pell-mell , and still my name is Sforza.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Sir your noble friend don Sebastian is at the castle gate

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your brother lady, and my honoured friend,
Why do the gates not spread themselves, to open
At his arrival Sforza, 'tis Berinthia's brother,
Sebastiano the example of all worth
And friendship, is come after his sweet sister,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Alas I fear.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Be not such a coward lady, he cannot come
Without all goodness waiting on him, Sforza,
Sforza I say, what precious time we lose,
Sebastiano, I almost lose myself
In joy to meet him, break the iron bar
and give him entrance.
