sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: I'll break the walls down, if the gates be too little.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I much desire to see him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sister, now he's come, he did promise me
But a short absence, he of all the world
I would call brother, Castabella more
Than for his sister's love, o he's a man
Made up of merit, my Berinthia
Throw off all clouds, Sebastiano's come.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sent by my father to —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What, to see thee? he shall see thee here.
Respected like thyself, Berinthia,
Attended with Antonio, begirt with armies of thy servants
O my friend.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: 'Tis yet in question sir, and will not be
So easily proved.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: No sir, we'll make you prove yourself our friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What face have you put on? am I awake?
Or do I dream Sebastiano frowns.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Antonio I come not now to compliment,
While you were noble, I was not least of them
You called your friends, but you are guilty of
An action that destroys that name.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Bones a your father, does he come to swagger,
My name is Sforza then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more,
I guilty of an action so dishonourable
Has made me unworthy of your friendship;
Come you're not in earnest, 'tis enough I know
Myself Antonio.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Add to him ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Twas a foul breath delivered it, and wert any
But Sebastiano, he should feel the weight
Of such a falsehood.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sister you must along with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now by my father's soul, he that takes her hence
Unless she give consent, treads on his grave,
Sebastiano , you're unnoble then,
'Tis I that said it.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: So it seems .

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Antonio, for here I throw of all
The ties of love, I come to fetch a sister,
Dishonourably taken from her father;
Or with my sword to force thee render her:
Now if thou beest a soldier redeliver,
Or keep her with the danger of thy person ,
Thou canst not be my brother, till we first
Be allied in blood.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Promise me the hearing,
And that have any satisfaction,
Becomes my fame.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: So, so, he will submit himself, it will be our honour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Were in your power, would you not account it
A precious victory, in your sister's cause,
To die your sword with any blood of him,
Saved both her life and honour?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I were ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You have told yourself, and I have argument to prove this.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Why would you have me think, my sister owes to you such preservation?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O Sebastiano,
Thou dost not think what devil lies at home
Within a sister's bosom, Catalina,
(I know not with what worst of envy) laid
Force to this goodly building, and through poison
Had robbed the earth of more than all the world,
Her virtue.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You must not beat my resolution off
With these inventions sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Be not cozened,
With your credulity, for my blood, I value it
Beneath my honour, and I dare by goodness,
In such a quarrel kill thee: but hear all,
And than you shall have fighting your heart full.
Valasco was the man, appointed by
That goodly sister to steal Berinthia,
And lord himself of this possession,
Just at that time; but hear and tremble at it,
She by a cunning poison should have breathed
Her soul into his arms, within two hours,
And so Valasco should have born the shame
Of theft and murder; how do you like this sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You amaze me sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis true by honour's self, hear it confirmed,
And when you will, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Pity such valour should be employed,
Upon no better cause, they will inform him.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Hark you sir, d'ye think this is true?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I dare maintain it.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: That's another matter, why then the case is
Altered, what should we do fighting, and lose
Our lives to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Sf.
sp.l: It seems you are his second.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I am count de monte Nigro.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.p: And my names Sforza sir, you were not best to come here to brave us, unless you have more legs and arms at home, I have a saza shall pick holes in your doublet, and firk your shanks, my gallimaufry .

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I cannot but believe it, o Berinthia ,
I am wounded ere I fight.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Holds your resolve yet constant ▪ if you have
Better opinion of your sword, than truth,
I am bound to answer, but I would I had
Such an advantage 'gainst another man,
As the justice of my cause, all valour fights
But with a sail against it.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Take a time to inform your father sir, my noble
Cousin is to be found here constant.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: But will you back with me then?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Excuse me brother, I shall fall too soon
Upon my sister's malice, whose foul guilt
Will make me expect more certain ruin,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now Sebestiano
Puts on his judgement, and assumes his nobleness,
Whilst he loves equity.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And shall I carry shame
To Vilarezo's house, neglect of father,
Whose precepts binds me to return with her,
Or leave my life at Eluas, I must on,
I have heard you to no purpose, shall Berinthia
Back to Avero.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir she must not yet, 'tis dangerous.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Choose thee a second then, this count and I
Mean to leave honour here.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Honour me sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis done, Sebastiano shall report
〈◊〉 just and noble, Sforza swear
Upon my sword, o do not hinder me
If victory crown Sebastiano's arm.
I charge thee by thy honesty restore
This lady to him, on whose lip I seal
My unstained faith.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Umh, 'tis a rare physician, my spirit is abated.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And wilt thou be dishonoured?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O do not wrong the gentleman, believe it
Dishonour ne'er dwelled here, and he hath made
A most religious vow, not in a thought
To stain my innocence, he does not force me
Remember, what a noble friend, you make
A most just enemy, he saved my life,
Be not a murderer, take yet a time,
Run not yourself in danger for a cause
Carries so little justice.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Faith sir, if you please take a time to think on't, a month or two or three, they shall not say but we are honourable.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: You gave him to my heart a gentleman, Seb whisp.
Complete with goodness, will you rob the world
and me at once, alas I love him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Never man fought with a lesser heart, the conquest
Will be but many deaths, he is her brother,
My friend, this poor girl's joy.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: With all my heart, I'll post to Avero presently.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Let it be so Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Alas poor Castabella, what a conflict
Seest thou within thee, their fight woundeth thee,
And I must die, who ere hath victory:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then friend again, and as Sebastiano,
I bid him welcome, and who loves Antonio
Must speak that language.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Enough, not a masty upon the castle wall ,
But shall bark too, I congratulate thee, if thou
Beelest friend to the castle of Eluas, and still my name
Is Sforza.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well said my brave Adelautado, come Sebastiano ,
And my Birinthia by tomorrow we shall know
The truth of our felicity.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What are the nobles more than common men
When all their honour cannot free them from
Shame and abuse; as greatness were a mark
Stuck by them but to give direction
For men to shoot indignities upon them?
Are we called lords of riches we possess,
And can defend them from the ravishing hand
Of strangers, when our children are not safe
From thieves and robbers, none of us can challenge
Such right to wealth and fortunes of the world,
Being things without us; but our children are
Essential to us, and participate
Of what we are: part of our very nature,
Ourselves but cast into a younger mould,
And can we promise, but so weak assurance
Of so near treasures. O Villarezo shall
Thy age be trampled on, no, it shall not,
I will be known a father, Portugal
shall not report this infamy unrevenged,
It will be a bar in Vilarezo's arms
Passed all posterity;
Come Catalina , thou wilt stay with me,
Prepare to welcome home Sebastiano,
Whom I expect with honour, and that baggage
Ambitious girl Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Alas sir; censure not her too soon,
Till she appear are guilty.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Here's thy virtue still,
To excuse her Catalina, no believe it,
She's naught, passed hope, I have an eye can see
Into her very heart, thou art too innocent.
Valasco welcome too, Berinthia
Is not come home yet, but we shall seem her
Brought back with shame; and is't not justice ha?
What can be shame enough?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your daughter sir?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: My daughter? do not call her so, she has not
True blood of Vilarezo in her veins;
She makes herself a bastard, and deserves
To be cut off like a disordered branch,
Disgracing the fair tree she springeth from.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Lay not so great a burden on Berinthia,
Her nature knows not to degenerate;
Upon my life she was not yielding, to
The injurious action; if Antonio
Have played the thief, let your revenge fall there,
Which were I trusted with, although I doubt not
Sebastiano's fury ; he should feel it
More heavy than his castle, what can be
Too just for such a sin?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Right, right Valasco, I do love thee fort,
'Tis so, and thou shalt see I have a sense
Worthy my birth and person.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'T will become you; but I marvel we hear nothing
Of their success at Eluas . by this time
I would have sent Antonio to warm
His father's ashes, do you not think sir?
Sebastiano will not be remiss,
A gentle nature is abused with tales,
Which they know how to colour; here's the count.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: How, the count? I sent him thither to be rid on him;
The fool has better fortune than I wished him,
But now I shall hear that which will more comfort me,
My sister's death most certainly.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: My lord, I have rid hard, read there, your son
And daughter is well.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Ha, well?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: How does my sister?

sp.speaker: Mount,
sp.l: In good health, she has commendations to you
In that letter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And is Antonio living?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Yes, and remembers his service to you,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Has he then yielded up Berinthia?

sp.speaker: Mo ●.
sp.l: He will yield up his ghost first, I know not we were
Going to flesh baste one another, I am sure but the
Matter of felony hangs still, who will cut it down;
I know not, madam there's notable matter against you.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Me?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Upon my honour there is, be not angry with me,
No less than theft and murder, that letter is charged
Withal, but you'll clear all I make no question, they talk of poisoning.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Am I betrayed ?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Well, I smell, I smell.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: What do you smell?

sp.speaker: Moun ●.
sp.l: It was but a trick of theirs to save their lives,
For we were bent to kill all that came against us.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Catalina read here, Valasco, both of you,
And let me read your faces, ha? they wonder.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How ● this, I steal Berinthia?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I poison my sister.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This doth amaze me.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Father, this letter says I would have poisoned my poor sister, innocence defend me.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: It will, it shall, come Jacquit you both,
They must not thus fool me.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Madam I thought as much, my mind gave me, it
Was a l ●e, yes, you look like a poisoner, as much
As I look like a hobby-horse.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Was ever honest love so abused, have I
So poor reward for my affection.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: It shall be so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Madam I know not how the poison came in, but I
Fear some have betrayed our plot.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: And how came you off my noble count.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As you see without any wounds, but much against
My will I was but one, Sebastiano, that was the
Principal, took a demur upon their allegation:
It seems, and so the matter is raked up in the embers.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To make a greater fire, were you so cold
To credit his excuse, Antonio,
I should not have been so frozen,
As you love honour and revenge, give me
Some interest now, and if I do not
Show myself faithful, let Valasco have
No name within your memory, let me beg ▪
To be your proxy sir, pity such blood,
As yours should be ignobly cast away;
Madam speak for me.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: No, i had rather lost this fool.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: And you can get their consents.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: You cannot sir in honour now go back.
I shall not think you love me, if my father
Point you such noble service to refuse it.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: You hear what she says.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Count monte Nigro.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am all fire with rage.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Valasco, you may accompany the count,
There may be employment of your valour too;
Tell me at your return, whether my son
May prove a soldier, here's new warrant for
Antonio's death, if there be coldness urge it,
'Tis my desire, I'll study a better service.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Away then both, no compliment, I wish you either
Had a Pegasus, be happy, my old blood boils, this
Must my peace secure, such sores as these must
have a desperate cure.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This honour madam of yourself and brother,
Make me unhappy, when I remember, what
I came for, not to feast thus but to fight.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Pity true friendship should thus suffer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Music.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Some conceit of Sforza the old captain ▪
Let's entertain it, some soldier's device,
A mask of soldiers.
Godamercy Sforza .

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: To your stations now my brave brats of military
Discipline, enough, Sforza honours you, look to your
Charge bullies, and be ready upon all occasions,
My invincible dub-a-dub knights of the castle,
Qui vala.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We must speak with don Sebastiano.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Must? Thou'rt a mushroom, mustin the castle of el ●●●,
Monte Nigro gives a letter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Friends; Sforza.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What , courting ladies, by this time 'twas expected
You would have courted fame sir, and wooed her to you;
You shall know me better.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I doubt you'll never be better, you shall now owe me
More than you shall account for.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Or else my curse, that word cries out for death.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My feats perplex me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Madam I do wonder
You can forget your honour, and reflect
On such unworthiness, wherein hath Valasco
Showed you less merit.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sir it becomes not me
To weigh your worths, nor would I learn of you
How to preserve my honour.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sister.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Villandras .

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Then i must take my leave, for I am sent for,
I am sorry for your fate, madam I am expected
by a father your virtue hath made me yours.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: O admirable physician ●

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sforza , there is no remedy, but by all honour do it,
Sister, I am to wait on him, o my poor girl
〈…〉 be with thee, for a
〈…〉 my absence.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: You may walk sir.
Antonio I must but now look on, you were
Best take 〈…〉 to out live him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 〈◊〉, I know not with what soul
I draw my sword against thee
Antonio I am driven in a storm
To 〈◊〉 myself on thee, if not, any curse —
We must on sir.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Rare man of art Sharkino.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Guard thee count.

div.stage: Enter Sfor. Val. and ladies above.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Treacherous Sforza , hast thou brought us hither, to be stroke dead?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Hold gentlemen, give me audience.

sp.speaker: Se ●.
sp.l: What's the matter my lord.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: 〈…〉 I had forgotten myself,
This is my ague day.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Yes a sextile ague, look you, do you not see me shake, 〈◊〉 doctor, it will be as much as my life is worth if I should fight a stroke.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Hell on such baseness, we'll engage no more;
Let our swords try it out.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sebastiano hold, thou'rt not so ill be friended,
Exchange a person, I'll leap the battlement.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Withal my heart, I am sorry it happens so unfortunately , o rare physician !

sp.l: Good cousin grant it.

sp.speaker: ●nt
sp.l: What says 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: V ●●.
sp.l: I conjure you by all honour.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It is granted;

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: He shall nor go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Me ●e him my lord, you will become his place of a
spectator best.

sp.speaker: Ber
sp.l: Sebastiano brother.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Antonio, hear me.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Guard thee Valasco then.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O brother spare him for my sake.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sebastiano every wound thou givest him,
Draws blood from me.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sebastiano, remember he's thy friend.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Antonio 'tis my brother, with whose blood
Thou diest thy sword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: When thou livest again shalt be more honourable
Sebastiano do you observe the advantage,
Yet think upon't.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It is not in my power. I value not the odds.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Hold, Antonio, is this thy love to me, it is not noble.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: So thy death makes the scale even.

sp.speaker: C ●st
sp.l: Antonio hold, Berinthia dies.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sebastiano, Castabella sinks for sorrow, murder, help
I will leap down.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where art Berinthia, let me breathe my last upon thy lip, make haste, lest I die else.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Antonio before thou diest cut off my hand, art wounded mortally?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To die by thee is more than death, Sforza be honest,
But love thy sister for me, I me past hope,
Thou hast undone another in my death.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Antonio stay o cruel brother ▪

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Berinthia thy lip farewell, and friend, and all the world.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: The gate is open, I am sworn to render.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: He's not dead, his lips are warm, have you no balsam, a surgeon ; dead, some charitable hand send my soul after him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It will be easy to die,
All life is but a walk in misery.

div.head: Actus 5. Scaen. 1.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: My friend, my noble friend, that had deserved
Most honourably from me, by this hand
Divorced from life, and yet I have the use on't,
Hapless Sebastiano; o Berinthia,
Let me for ever lose the name of brother,
Wilt thou not curse my memory, give me up
To thy just hate a murderer.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Ha, this must not be Sebastiano,
I shall be angry if you throw not off
This melancholy, it does ill become you,
Do you repent your duty, were the action
Again presented to be done by thee:
And being done, again should challenge from thee
A new performance, thou wouldst show no blood
Of Villarezo's, if thou didst not run
To act it, though all horror, death and vengeance
Dogged thee at thy heels; come I am thy father,
Value my blessing, and for other peace
I'll to the King, let me no more see thee cloudy.

div.stage: Enter Diego, Castabella like a page.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: That was his father.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No more, farewell, be all silence.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He's newly gone that way, mayst soon o'er take him

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My business points at you sir.

sp.speaker: Seb,
sp.p: At me, what news? thou hast a face of horror, more welcome speak it.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: If your name be don Sebastiano, sir
I have a token from a friend.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I have no friend alive boy, carry it back,
'Tis not to me, I've not another friend
In all the world.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: He that hath sent you sir this gift, did love you,
You'll say yourself he did.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ha, name him prithee.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: The friend I came from was Antonio.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou liest, and thou'rt a villain, who hath sent thee
To tempt Sebastiano's soul to act on thee
Another death, for thus affrighting me.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Indeed I do not mock, nor come to affright you
Heaven knows my heart, I know Antonio's dead,
But 'twas a gift he in his life designed
To you, and I have brought it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou dost not promise cozenage, what gift is it?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: It is myself sir, while Antonio lived, I was his boy,
But never did boy lose so kind a master, in his life he
Promised he would bestow me, so much was his love
To my poor merit, on his dearest friend,
And named you sir, if heaven should point out
To overlive him, for he knew you would
Love me the better for his sake, indeed
I will be very honest to you, and
Refuse no service to procure your love
And good opinion to me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Can it be
Thou wert his boy, o thou shouldst hate me then,
Thou'rt false, I dare not trust thee, unto him
Thou showest thee now unfaithful to accept
Of me, I killed him thy master, 'twas a friend
He could commit thee to, I only was,
Of all the stock of men his enemy,
His cruelest enemy.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Indeed I am sure it was, he spoke all truth,
And had he lived to have made his will, I know
He had bequeathed me as a legacy
To be your boy; alas I am willing sir
To obey him in it, had he laid on me
Command, to have mingled with his sacred dust,
My unprofitable blood, it should have been
A most glad sacrifice, and 'thad been honour
to have done him such a duty sir, I know
You did not kill him with a heart of malice,
But in contention with your very soul
To part with him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: All is as true as oracle by heaven,
Dost thou believe so?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Indeed I do.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Yet be not rash;
'Tis no advantage to belong to me,
I have no power nor greatness in the court,
To raise thee to a fortune, worthy of
So much observance as I shall expect
When thou art mine.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: All the ambition of my thoughts shall be
To do my duty sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Besides, I shall afflict thy tenderness
With solitude and passion, for I am
Only in love with sorrow, never merry,
Wear out the day in telling of sad tales,
Delight in sighs and tears; sometimes I walk
To a wood or river purposely to challenge
The boldest echo, to send back my groans
Ith' height I break 'em, come I shall undo thee.

sp.speaker: Cast,
sp.l: Sir, I shall be most happy to bear part
In any of your sorrows, I ne'er had
So hard a heart but I could shed a tear
To bear my master company.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I will not leave thee if thou'lt dwell with me
For wealth of Indies, be my loved boy,
Come in with me, thus I'll begin to do
Some recompense for dead Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: So I will dare my fortune to be cruel,
And like a mountainous piece of earth that sucks
The balls of hot artillery, I will stand
And weary all the gunshot; o my soul
Thou hast been too long icy Alps of snow;
Have buried my whole nature, it shall now
Turn element of fire, and fill the air
With bearded comets , threatening death and horror
for my wronged innocence, contemned, disgraced ,
Nay murdered, for with Antonio
My breath expired, and I but borrow this
To court revenge for justice, if there be
Those furies which do wait on desperate men,
As some have thought, and guide their hands to mischief.
Come from the womb of night, assist a maid
Ambitious to be made a monster like you;
I will not dread your shapes, I am disposed
To be at friendship with you, and want naught
But your black aid to seal it.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: First I'll lock up thy
Tongue, and tell thee my honourable meaning, so,
To tell you the truth, it is a love-powder, i had it of the
Brave doctor, which I would have thee to sugar
The lady's cup withal, for my sake wilt do't:
And if I marry her shalt find me a noble
Master, and thou shalt be my chief gentlewoman
In ordinary; keep thy body loose, and thou shalt
Want no gown I warrant thee; wilt do't.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My lord, I think my lady is much taken with your
Worth already, so that this will be superfluous,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I nay think she has cause enough, but I have a great
Mind to make an end on't, to tell you true, there are
Half a dozen about me, but I had rather she should have
Me than another; and my blood is grown so boisterous
For my body, that's another thing; so that if thou wilt
Do it Ansilva, thou wilt do thy lady good service,
And live in the favour of count de monte Nigro ●;
I will make thy children kin to me, if thou wilt
Do't.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I am your honour's handmaid, but —

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Here's a diamond, prithee wear it, be not modest.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: 'Tis done my lord, urge it no further.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: But be secret too for my honour's sake, we great men
Do not love to have our actions laid open to the
Broad face of the world, I'll get thee with child,
And marry thee to a knight, my brave Ansilva, take
the first opportunity.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: If there be any virtue in the powder, prepare to
Meet your wishes my noble lord.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Thy count de monte Nigro expect to be a lady.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ansilva.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nay you need not hide it, I heard the conference,
And know the virtue of the powder, let me see it
Or I'll discover all.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, here take it again, I'll not prevent
My sister's happiness and the counts desire,
I am no tell-tale good Ansilva give't her,
And heavens succeed the operation,
I beg on my knee; fear not Ansilva,
I am all silence.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Indeed madam, than she shall have it presently.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sir, if the opportunity I use
To comfort you be held a fault, and that
I keep not distance of a servant, lay it
Upon my love; indeed if it be an error
It springs out of my duty.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Prithee boy be patient;
The more I strive to throw off the remembrance
Of dead Antonio, love still rubs the wounds
To make them bleed afresh.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Alas they are past,
Bind up your own for honour's sake,
And show love to yourself, pray do not lose your reason,
To make your grief so fruitless; I have procured
Some music sir to quiet those sad thoughts,
That makes such war within you.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Alas good boy, it will but add more weights
Of dulness on me, I am stung with worse
Than the tarantula, to be cured with music
'T has the exactest unity, but it cannot,
Accord my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sir this your couch
seems to invite so small repose;
O I beseech you taste it, I'll beg
A little leave to sing;
Sweet sleep charm his sad senses, and gentle
Thoughts let fall your flowing numbers, here round
About hover celestial angels with your wings
That none offend his quiet, sleep begins
To cast his nets o'er me too, I'll obey,
And dream on him, that dreams not what I am.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nature doth wrestle with me, but revenge
Doth arm my love against it, justice is
Above all tie of blood Sebastiano
Thou art the first shalt tell Antonio's ghost
How much I loved him.

div.stage: She stabbes him upon his couch; Castab. rises and runs in.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: O stay thy hand Berinthia? no
Thou'st don't, I wish thee heavens forgiveness, I cannot
Tarry to hear thy reasons, at many doors,
My life runs out, and yet Berinthia
Doth in her name give me more wounds than these,
Antonio, o Antonio, we shall now
Be friends again.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: He's dead, and yet I live, but not to fall
Less than a constellation, more flames must
Make up the fire that Berinthia
And her revenge, must bathe in.

div.stage: Enter Catalina poisoned, pulling Ansilva by the hair.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sebastiano, sister.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Murder.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: There's wildfire in my bowels, sure I am poisoned;
O Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Help me to tear Ansilva, I am poisoned by
The count and this fury.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Do you laugh hereat.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes Queen of hell to see thee
Sink in the glory of thy hope for bliss:
But art sure th' art poisoned, ha?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Nay I have my part on't, I did but sip, and my belly
swell to ●; call you this love-powder, count monte
Nigro hath poisoned us both.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You're a pair of witches, and because
I'll keep your potion working, know you're both
Poisoned by me, by me Berinthia,
Being thus tormented with my wrongs,
I armed myself with all provision
For my revenge, and had in readiness
That faithful poison which ith' opportunity
I put upon Ansilva for the exchange
Of the amorous powder; o fools, my soul
Ravish thyself with laughter, Politsion
My eldest devil sister, does the heat
Offend your stomach, troth charity, a little charity
Th'only antidote, that's cold enough:
Look here's Sebastiano;
Now horror strike thy soul, to whose fearless heart
I sent this poniard, for Antonio's death;
And if that piece of thy damnation
Ansilva had not don't, I meant to have writ
Revenge with the same point upon thy breast;
But I do surfeit in this brave prevention:
Sleep, sleep Antonio's ashes, and now open
Thou marble chest to take Berinthia
To mingle with his dust.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I have not so much heart as to curse, must I die?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Here my lord, alas he's dead, my Sebastiano

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Catalina.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I am poisoned.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Ha, defend good heaven, by whom.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I am poisoned too.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Rack not my soul amazement, 'tis a dream sure.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Your love-powder hath poisoned us both.

sp.speaker: Mou.
sp.l: What will become of me now, I would I were hanged
To be out of my pain, by this flesh, as I am a count.
I bought it of the doctor for good love-powder;
But madam I hope you are not poisoned in earnest.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: The devil on your foolship, o I must walk
the dark foggy way that spits fire and brimstone,
No physic to restore me? send for Sharkino, a cooler
A cooler, there ● a smith's forge in my belly, and the
Devil blows the bellows, snow-water, Berinthia
Has poisoned me, sink by mine own engine;
I must hence, hence, farewell, will you let me die so?
Confusion, torment, death, hell.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I am glad with all my heart that Berinthia has
Poisoned her, yet —

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O it becomes thee bravely, hear me sir.
Antonio's death and my dishonours now
Have just revenge; I stabbed Sebastiano, poisoned my sister,
O but they made too soon a fury of me,
And split the patience, from whose dreadful breach
Came these consuming fires, your passions fruitless;
My soul is reeling forth I know not whether;
O father my heart weeps tears, for you I die, o see
A maid's revenge with her own tragedy.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Ansilva, o thou dull wretch, hell on thy cursed
Weakness, thou gavest me
The poison, but I lick earth, hold, a gentleman
Usher to support me, o I am gone, the poison
Now hath torn my heart in pieces, moritur.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I am planet struck, a direful tragedy, and have
I no part in't: how do you like it, ha? wast not
Done toth' life? they are my own children; this was
My eldest girl, this Berinthia the tragedian,
Whose love by me resisted, was mother of all this
Horror; and there's my boy too, that slew Antonio
Valiantly, and fell under his sister's rage, what
Art thou boy?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I'll tell you now I am no boy,
But hapless Castabella, sister to
The slain Antonio, I had hoped to have
Some recompense by Sebastiano's love,
For whose sake in disguise I thus adventured
To purchase it, but death hath ravished us,
And here I bury all my joys on earth.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Sweet lady, here's count de monte Nigro alive
To be your servant.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Hence dull greatness.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Were you a friend of Sebastiano then?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I'll give you testimony.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: No, I believe you, but thou canst not be my daughter;
'Tis false, he lies that says Beriathia
Was author of their deaths, 'twas Villarezo ●,
A father's wretched curiosity, dead, dead, dead.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: And I will leave the world too, for I mean
To spend the poor remainder of my days
In some religious house, married to heaven,
And holy prayers for Sebastiano's soul,
And my lost brother.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Will you so?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I pray let Castabella have the honour
To enshrine his bones, and when my breath expires,
For sorrow promiseth I shall not live
To see more suns, let me be buried by him
As near as may be possible, that in death
Our dust may meet, o my Sebastiano,
Thy wounds are mine.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Come I am armed, take up their bodies, Castabella you
Are not chief mourner here, he was my son,
Remember that, Berinthia first, she was the
Youngest, put her ith' pit-hole first, than Catalina;
Strew, strew flowers enough upon 'em, for they
Were maids; now Sebastiano, take him
Up gently, he was all the sons I had; now
March, come you and I are twins in this day's
Unhappiness, we'll match together, follow close
We'll overtake 'em, softly, and as we go,
We'll dare our fortune for another woe.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
